title: Why Am I Spotting Between Periods?
author: Katie Cameron

content: Most women have spotting between their periods at some point. Usually, it's nothing to worry about. Several things can cause it. These are the most common:
bullets: Hormone-based birth control. If you're on birth control that contains hormones (pills, patches, shots, rings, or implants), you might spot during the first three months of using it. Doctors call this "breakthrough bleeding." They believe the extra hormones may cause changes in the lining of your uterus.
Some sexually transmitted infections (STIs), such as chlamydia
Infection of the cervix or lining of your uterus
Blood clotting disorders, such as von Willebrand disease
Other health conditions, such as hypothyroidism , liver disease, or chronic kidney disease
Fibroids or polyps. These are noncancerous tumors that grow in the lining or muscle of the uterus.

Polycystic ovary syndrome ( PCOS ). If you have this condition, your ovaries don't release eggs the way they should. Your ovaries become enlarged with fluid-filled sacs that surround your eggs. Your body also makes too many male hormones (called androgens). This can lead to irregular periods, spotting, and sometimes no period at all.

Cancers of the reproductive system. These include uterine cancer . They're most common in women who've already gone through menopause . But if you're over 40 and spotting between periods, see the doctor to rule out more serious problems.
Perimenopause. As you get closer to menopause, your periods might be harder to predict. Your hormone levels change, and the lining of your uterus gets thicker. This can sometimes lead to spotting.

sections.heading: When Should I Call the Doctor About Spotting Between Periods?
content: Make an appointment if spotting concerns you or if you have spotting along with the following symptoms:
You may want to contact your doctor if you have spotting between periods and lower stomach pain. (Photo Credit: iStock/Getty Images)
Spotting is different from persistent bleeding , and anyone with persistent, heavy, or prolonged bleeding should make an appointment to get it checked out.
You should also see a doctor if you think you might be pregnant.
Call 911 if you have unusual vaginal bleeding with:

Take notes about your menstrual cycle and the length and heaviness of the bleeding to help your doctor figure out what's going on. They may order blood tests or other tests, such as a transvaginal ultrasound or endometrial biopsy.
bullets: Pain in your lower abdomen
Fever
Symptoms that get worse or happen more often
Any type of vaginal bleeding — including spotting — after you've gone through menopause
Lightheadedness
Fainting
Skin that appears unusually pale

sections.heading: What Are the Complications of Spotting Between Periods?
content: Abnormal vaginal bleeding may be minor. But it could signal something more serious or even life-threatening, such as a benign growth like a polyp or fibroid, a bleeding disorder , an infection, or an injury. It's rare, but spotting can sometimes be a sign of cancer. To be safe, have your doctor check it out.

sections.heading: Other Reasons for Irregular Bleeding
content: You can expect your period to stop when you're pregnant. But 15%-25% of women have some bleeding during the first trimester.
If you're pregnant and find more than a little bit of blood, especially after the first trimester, call your doctor right away. This could be a sign of:

Menopause is when you permanently stop getting your period, but it doesn't happen overnight. You may have symptoms for years. A common one is light, irregular bleeding, which might seem like bloody discharge.

There's another reason why women in the early stages of menopause often have unusual vaginal bleeding. Some of them take hormone replacement therapy (HRT) to control their symptoms. HRT is a common cause of uterine bleeding.

Don't assume that any blood you see is because of changes in your body as you near menopause or any medicine you take. It's better to play it safe and call your doctor, especially since endometrial and uterine cancer are more common in older women than in younger ones.
bullets: Light bleeding may happen one to two weeks after the fertilized egg implants in your womb.
Your cervix may bleed more easily as it gains more blood vessels.
You may notice spotting after sex, a Pap test, or a pelvic exam.
Miscarriage , which usually happens in the first 13 weeks
Ectopic pregnancy , when the fertilized egg implants outside the uterus
Preterm labor
Problems with your cervix
Problems with your placenta

content: If it's due to the contraception or menopause hormone therapy, you may want to try another contraception or a different pill.
Your bleeding could also be due to some type of polyp, fibroid, or thickening in your endometrium.
If it is a polyp, get it checked to make sure it is not cancerous. Surgery could be an option for removing benign (noncancerous) polyps.
Here are some of the treatment options:
If you have some type of infection, your doctor may give you antibiotics . They may also check for an STI and give you and your partner the right treatment.
bullets: Dilation and curettage (D&C): Involves scraping of tissue from your uterus lining
Endometrial ablation: Destroys the lining of your uterus
Myomectomy: Removes fibroids, but not your uterus
Hysterectomy: Removes your uterus
Uterine artery embolization: Blocks vessels that fibroids use to grow

sections.heading: Takeaways
content: A day or two of spotting between periods is normal, but if you notice more bleeding than normal, talk to your doctor. Possible causes could include pregnancy, hormonal imbalances, STIs, certain hormonal birth control options, conditions such as PCOS, endometrial polyps, or uterine fibroids. Your doctor can help you narrow down the cause of the bleeding and figure out the best treatment plan for you.

sections.heading: Spotting Between Periods FAQs
content: It's normal to have a day or two of spotting during ovulation or if you use hormonal birth control options such as a hormonal IUD , the Depo-Provera injection, or birth control pills.
Yes, stress can affect your hormone levels and cause spotting between periods.
Spotting between periods can happen for many reasons, but a common cause is an imbalance of your estrogen and progesterone levels, which are released when you ovulate.
